text:
Hi guys, hope you're well. So I want to tell
you a lovely little story about the most

amazing smoked salmon, these stories I
believe need to be told about talented

people that put everything on the line
and everything into making the very very

best, check this out this is a story of
the secret smokehouse.

There was this amazing old chap who
smoked kippers on the west coast of

Scotland and just south of Loch Gilb
and it was just this ancient old

smokehouse we'd go there in the Saturday
morning and we would always go and ask them

what they did it was always secret
secret this secret that which then has

obviously kind of got an influence on
the name of the business. It started by

complete accident
I came to a junction in my career, working

career and 15 years in London working
away and then I went back up Scotland to

kind of decompress from the whole thing built
this smoker using pallets to start

smoking fish and I then came back down
to London to basically figure out what

what it was that I was doing lived in and
around the East End of London for about

15 years but just moved into a place down in Stepney.
My fish filleting was

appalling like I'd hacked away at it and right
next to Stepney is of course

Billingsgate fish market so I thought
actually I think I'm going to improve my skills so

I enrolled in this amazing fish
mongering course down at Billingsgate. Then

something dawned on me you know that
Eureka moment, why don't I build another

smoker in the back garden? Off I set,
three hundred quid my back pocket bought

shed all the equipment you need to do it and
you know my new skill of being able to

fillet and I started producing it in
East End of London. All these coincidences

started happening and I unearthed all
this rich rich history of smoke houses

in Stepney and that was all by chance
when I walked into my local pub called

the peacock
proper East End Pub from the outside

definitely looks closed go in and then
you know almost like the music stops and

people's heads turn around and this
lovely old guy came up to me just

introduced himself and he offered
me a drink and he was like "alright boy" you

know "where are you from" you know "what
are you doing" I was like I've come for a drink

chatting away and all this
you know they're all amazing they've all

got amazing stories these these lovely
guys and it's like honestly you're like

putty in their hands just listening to
these incredible like when they were younger

or somebody used to work down
Billingsgate and then I was like oh I

smoke fish I'm smoking fish in the
back garden,

and they all their ears all pick up and
then tell me these incredible stories

about smoke houses that used to be round
in Stepney and then that's it they were

just like trying to suss out to see what
if I was legit yeah I think they thought

that I was an undercover policeman or
something like that it was it was very funny.

They then became ultimately my my litmus
paper for what was going on because I

you can't fool them if you give him a bit of
smoked haddock and it's not up to

scratch they'll they'll tell you they
will tell you and they won't mince their

words. The first time they tasted the
haddock and the kippers one of the

comments I'll never forget was it was
the best smoked haddock he'd he'd tasted

in like 25 years and I was just right ok
if if these guys are liking it then fine

let's just keep carrying on and that
confidence that they gave me I will

never forget how they in the peacock
just totally and utterly supported me

and then my milkman became my acado
delivery service and he started taking

orders on his milk run round Stepney
and I then started selling out and then

realized that there was a business
behind it there really wasn't a

no-frills smokehouse but just doing one
thing well and that was smoking it with

the old-fashioned way
not trying to infuse it not to be clever

just like really beautiful beautifully
sourced and then beautifully cured and

smoked fish. There also wasn't any plan B you
know it had to work you know if you're

gonna do this balls on the line go for
it and don't look back. Word got out that I was

smoking fish and a phone call came in from
from a chef, a meeting was put in the

diary and I didn't know what I was going into, the
environment anything whatsoever so I

kind of bounced along with a couple
of sides of smoked salmon under my arm

got taken into the kitchen and there was
this kitchen full of chefs like 20 chefs

and they all stopped and then the main
chef came in asked me a million

questions about what I was doing, how I was
doing it etc turning upside down, slicing

it, putting it up to the light, smelling it and
just generally just seeing what I was

doing was was genuine and if I was the
real McCoy or if I was you know blagging

it. He was just blown away by the flavour
I said are you just saying this

because I'm I'm stood in front of you?
You know for all the chef's behind this
guy like. Basically the chef was Claude Bosi, two Michelin star chef and he was
just blown away by it I think it took a long time for that to sink in you

become quite blinkered in what you're
doing and you only wanted to do

something I guess in a selfish way I
want to produce salmon like this

or smoked salmon this way and then all
of a sudden somebody tastes it like that

and you like oh okay right crikey
we've maybe got something here. We now

supply the most insane restaurants and
hotels here in London you can't pull wool

over these guys eyes if that flavour
that really important flavour that you're

trying to get into the fish that allows
them to hero it on the plate

and the magic ingredient or the secret
ingredient is I guess the passion and

the love of what we do there's something
romantic and also really amazing about

staying small and true to what it is and
why I set it up. The shed's here we have grown

not gonna lie but we never changed our
process we're not big mass-producer

we don't have big machines,
filleting machines, special things to

pin bone or fancy circular knives
everything is done by hand and with that

I think there's so much power in it. Why
be anything bigger than what you are

because as soon as you grow way to
big then you're just producing average

again
and that's not what I set it up for.
